1.12.text:
Sophie: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English.
I'm Sophie.

4.94.text:
Neil: And I'm Neil. I was watching the news
the other day, Sophie.

10.32.text:
Neil: Yes, actually. UK scientists have been
authorised by the government to genetically

19.12.text:
What they can't do though is implant modified
embryos into women.

23.60.text: They talked a lot about gene editing.

25.70.text:
Sophie: Can you explain to us what gene editing
is?

28.31.text:
Neil: Mmm... I think this means there are
these letters in a code

32.55.text: A-B-C something... I can't remember exactly...

36.52.text:
Sophie: Gene editing is the ability to manipulate
– or control – DNA.

41.72.text:
And in case you didn't know, DNA is short
for deoxyribonucleic acid

47.72.text: this is a substance in the cells of animals and plants that contains genetic information.

53.02.text:
And a gene is part of the DNA in the cell
that controls the physical development

58.00.text:
and behaviour of a plant or animal and is passed
on from its parents.

63.08.text:
Neil: Phew! Thanks for the science lesson,
Sophie.

65.71.text: Sophie: You're welcome. Now here's a question for you,

68.65.text: Which science fiction film anticipates gene editing in a dystopian society

74.03.text:
where humans are genetically engineered? Is it...
a) Robocop

79.34.text:
b) Gattaca
or c) Blade Runner

82.88.text:
Neil: Mmm... I don't really understand the
question but I'm going to say c) Blade Runner.

89.66.text:
Sophie: Dystopian means an imaginary society
where people are unhappy and afraid.

95.32.text:
Well, moving on, let's listen to BBC journalist
Fergus Walsh talking about how gene editing works.

103.16.text:
Fergus Walsh: Think of gene editing as a molecular
sat nav.

106.80.text: It scans the DNA searching for the error.

109.62.text: Then it uses molecular scissors to snip through both strands, which switches off the faulty gene.

116.08.text: Or it can repair the code by inserting a healthy copy of the gene.

121.44.text: These techniques raise the prospect of treating ... even curing – some genetic diseases

129.20.text:
Sophie: So DNA is a set of instructions for
how our bodies work

133.76.text: written using a chemical code of four letters – A, T, C, G.

140.21.text: But sometimes the code contains mistakes.

142.69.text: Neil: Yes. You find spelling mistakes by scanning – or searching – through the DNA.

147.61.text:
Then you snip – or cut out – the mistake
or faulty gene from the code using molecular scissors.

154.58.text: Faulty by the way, means something that isn't working properly ... like the faulty brakes on my bike.

159.76.text: Sophie: That sounds really dangerous, Neil!

161.78.text:
Neil: Yeah, but I'm more worried about my
faulty genes.

164.66.text: I might have all sorts of genetic mistakes inside me.

170.20.text: But you've actually touched on a serious point.

172.74.text:
Latest research suggests all our bodies do contain
genetic mistakes,

177.22.text: some of which could cause disease.

179.58.text:
And as reporter Fergus Walsh said
at the end of the clip,

182.82.text: gene editing could be important for treating or even curing inherited genetic diseases.

189.26.text: For patients with blood, immune, muscle or skin disorders

193.42.text: it offers the possibility that their faulty cells could be removed,

197.60.text: or changed in the lab, and then put back.

200.62.text:
Neil: That sounds amazing. But is there a
catch?

203.88.text: Sophie: And that means a problem or drawback.

206.92.text: Yes. Some people think that if editing the genes of a human embryo is allowed for curing disease,

213.40.text: this will lead to editing the genes of embryos for reasons other than health.

220.90.text: executive director of the Centre for Genetics and Society in California talking about her concerns.

228.72.text:
Marcy Darnovsky: It's too risky, we don't
need it, there are other ways to have healthy children,

232.88.text: and it would open the door – possibly – to a world of genetic haves and have nots.

237.78.text:
We don't need more inequality,
we don't need more discrimination in the world.

242.10.text:
Neil: An embryo by the way is an animal or
human starting to develop inside its mother.

247.98.text:
Marcy Darnovsky is against gene editing because
it may be used to create designer babies

253.78.text:
or babies whose genes have been selected to
have certain desirable characteristics.

258.82.text: Sophie: She says it may open the door

261.62.text: or make it possible – a situation where

264.80.text: embryos are genetically enhanced or improved ... to be more intelligent or physically stronger, for example.

272.16.text:
Neil: And this will lead to more discrimination
in the world

274.98.text: which means treating some people less fairly than others.

278.10.text:
Sophie: which is something that science fiction
has been predicting for many years.

282.22.text:
It's that dystopian society we were discussing earlier,
Neil!

286.14.text: Which science fiction film anticipates gene editing in a dystopian society

294.56.text: Is it... a) Robocop b) Gattaca or c) Blade Runner?

300.16.text: Neil: And I said c) Blade Runner.

302.83.text: Sophie: Sorry, Neil! It was b) Gattaca.

306.63.text: This 1997 sci-fi film centres on the character Vincent Freeman,

311.50.text: who wasn't genetically engineered, but is able to buy the genetic identity of another man

318.10.text: in order to pursue his dream of travelling into space.

322.06.text: The film's title uses the letters G, A, T and C, which are the four chemical codes making up DNA.

353.96.text:
Neil: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute
English.

356.30.text: Please do join us again soon!
